Skin Color (hex)/Feedback: Less is more when it comes to jewelry. Small, simple pieces aren't distracting and fit the occasion.
Save your more flashy and fun jewelry for a night out with friends. Loud jewelry can be distracting in an interview.
A button-up blouse that's not too tight and not too big is traditionally associated with professional attire.
A loose-fitting blouse like this might have been appropriate, but it being cropped makes it too informal for an interview.
Low-cut shirts are considered revealing and can suggest a lack of awareness or professionalism, even if that’s not your intent.
If not too short and not too tight, a pencil skirt doesn’t draw too much attention to itself, keeping the focus on who you are as a candidate.
Capris are often associated with casual, warm-weather, or leisure wear. There are more professional options for an interview.
Skirts should ideally fall at or just below the knee. Anything too short can appear unprofessional or inappropriate for a formal setting.
Appropriate for an interview because they align closely with traditional standards of professionalism, modesty, and formality.
Comfy, but more appropriate for a casual setting. Business casual footwear usually covers most of the foot.
Exposed toes can be viewed as too revealing, and might give the impression that you're not fully aware of professional expectations.
